message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest liver dysfunction, and the Doppler ultrasound indicates reduced blood flow. The laboratory results show significantly elevated levels of liver enzymes, which are markers of liver damage. The high serum bilirubin level suggests impairment of bilirubin metabolism, which is a function of hepatocytes. Option D suggests interstitial cellular infiltration with parenchymal fibrosis, obliterative arteritis, which are characteristic features of chronic rejection of transplanted liver.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's history and laboratory findings suggest that he has acute liver failure, and the Doppler ultrasound shows reduced blood flow to the transplanted liver. Among the options, only (D) Interstitial cellular infiltration with parenchymal fibrosis, obliterative arteritis is consistent with acute rejection of the liver transplant. Other options suggest chronic liver disease, which is not supported by the acute presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest the patient has post-transplantation hepatic artery thrombosis, which causes ischemic injury to the liver. The most likely histological feature is interstitial cellular infiltration with parenchymal fibrosis and obliterative arteritis. Option B suggests cirrhosis, which is not the most likely diagnosis in this case. Option C suggests nonalcoholic fatty liver disease, which is also unlikely given the patient’s history of liver transplantation. Option A suggests normal liver architecture, which is not consistent with the laboratory findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical jaundice and elevated liver enzymes suggest liver dysfunction, and the reduced blood flow into the transplanted liver suggests graft rejection. Option D describes the histological features of acute rejection, which is a common complication after liver transplantation. Option A is not likely due to the patient's symptoms and laboratory results, while options B and C are more characteristic of chronic liver disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical presentation and laboratory findings suggest an acute liver failure, most likely due to ischemia-reperfusion injury caused by reduced blood flow into the transplanted liver. Option D describes the histological features of chronic rejection, which can develop in the long term after liver transplantation, but it is unlikely to be present in this case. Options A and C are not consistent with the clinical picture. Option B describes the histological features of cirrhosis, which can occur in the long term after liver transplantation, but it is unlikely to be present in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The decrease in blood flow to the transplanted liver and the high liver function test results suggest ischemic cholangiopathy. The histological feature of interstitial cellular infiltration with parenchymal fibrosis and obliterative arteritis may be seen in ischemic cholangiopathy. Normal architecture of bile ducts and hepatocytes (A) would not explain the high bilirubin levels and liver function test results. Broad fibrous septations with formation of micronodules (B) would suggest cirrhosis, which would not be expected in a patient who underwent liver transplantation 7 years ago. Ballooning degeneration of hepatocytes (C) may be seen in hepatitis, but the clinical scenario and laboratory findings suggest ischemic cholangiopathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history of repeated episodes of yellowish skin discoloration and elevated liver enzymes along with reduced blood flow into the transplanted liver suggest chronic rejection. The histological features of chronic rejection include interstitial cellular infiltration with parenchymal fibrosis and obliterative arteritis. The other options describe histological features of other liver diseases such as cirrhosis, nodular regenerative hyperplasia, and ballooning degeneration.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history, physical examination, and laboratory studies suggest a diagnosis of hepatic artery thrombosis. This can lead to graft failure and result in interstitial cellular infiltration with parenchymal fibrosis, and obliterative arteritis. Options (A), (B), and (C) do not match the expected histological features.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history of similar episodes and elevated liver enzymes suggest that the transplanted liver is experiencing chronic rejection. The reduced blood flow shown on Doppler ultrasound suggests obliterative arteritis, which is characterized by interstitial cellular infiltration with parenchymal fibrosis. Therefore, the answer is (D).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms (yellowish discoloration of skin and urine), high levels of serum bilirubin, AST, ALT, and alkaline phosphatase suggest some form of liver damage. The reduced blood flow into the transplanted liver further confirms this. Among the options, interstitial cellular infiltration with parenchymal fibrosis, obliterative arteritis best describes the features of chronic rejection, which is a common cause of liver transplant failure in the long term.
